glossary/coalesce.html.title: Coalesce
glossary/coalesce.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
glossary/coalesce.html.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
Takes first non-NULL value
SELECT COALESCE(1, NULL) ------ 1 SELECT COALESCE(NULL, 3) ------ 3 SELECT COALESCE(1, 2) --------- 1 SELECT COALESCE(NULL, NULL) --- NULL Copy
Natural full joins model COALESCE
M = {(a: [1, 2])} N = {(a: [2, 3])} SELECT * FROM M NATURAL FULL JOIN N --- {(a: 1, 2, 3)} Copy
glossary/coalesce.html.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

glossary/common-table-expressions.html.title: Common Table Expressions
glossary/common-table-expressions.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
glossary/common-table-expressions.html.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
WITH clause defines a temporary table only available to the to the query it occurs in.
Useful when same intermediate table needs to be accessed multiple times
WITH X AS (SELECT product, SUM(quantity) AS TQ FROM purchase GROUP BY product) SELECT MAX(TQ) AS MTQ FROM X Copy
glossary/common-table-expressions.html.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

glossary/commutativity-&-associativity.h.title: Commutativity & Associativity
glossary/commutativity-&-associativity.h.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
glossary/commutativity-&-associativity.h.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
Commutativity:
Associativity:
where is a binary operator. Scalar multiplication is both commutative and associative whereas matrix multiplication is associative but not commutative
Outerjoins are commutative but not associative
glossary/commutativity-&-associativity.h.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

glossary/correlated-nested-queries.html.title: Correlated Nested Queries
glossary/correlated-nested-queries.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
glossary/correlated-nested-queries.html.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
When the WHERE clause of a nested query references some table in the outer query, the two queries are said to be correlated
Where in uncorrelated queries, you could evaluate the inner query and then evaluate the outer query, in a correlated query, the inner query has to be evaluated for each tuple of the outer query (semantic evaluation)
glossary/correlated-nested-queries.html.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

glossary/excel.html.description:
Unit 1 - SQL
What is the most popular PL?
?
Microsoft Excel. As of 2023, Excel is Turing-complete.

Find proof for Turing-complete.

glossary/full-disjunction.html.title: Full Disjunction
glossary/full-disjunction.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
glossary/full-disjunction.html.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
A join-operator variant that maximally combines join consistent tuples from connected relations, while preserving all information in the relations. Two tuples from two different relations are join consistent if they agree on common attributes
glossary/full-disjunction.html.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

glossary/join-types.html.title: Join Types
glossary/join-types.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
glossary/join-types.html.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL

Starting from top left, going the "U" and then the center
LEFT OUTER JOIN LEFT ANTI JOIN FULL OUTER JOIN FULL ANTI JOIN RIGHT ANTI JOIN RIGHT OUTER JOIN INNER JOIN; If only A or B - SEMI JOIN (ANTI-ANTI-JOINS) Copy
glossary/join-types.html.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

glossary/matrix-chain-multiplication.htm.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
What is the optimal sequence to multiply matrices to minimize computation cost? Intuition is that we want all intermediate matrices to be small
All possible ways to parenthesize: Catalan Number
via Dynamic Programming:
Best known:
glossary/matrix-chain-multiplication.htm.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

glossary/monotone-queries.html.title: Monotone Queries
glossary/monotone-queries.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
glossary/monotone-queries.html.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
A query is monotone if whenever tuples are added to the input/base relations, the size of the output relation cannot decrease
Conjunctive SQL queries like SELECT-FROM-WHERE are monotone i.e. if tuples are added to the input relations, the output relation size can never get smaller
(Unit 1 - SQL) All unnested queries are {{monotone}}
(Unit 1 - SQL) Queries with {{universal quantifier}} are not monotone
(Unit 1 - SQL) We cannot unnest a query with a {{universal quantifier}}
glossary/monotone-queries.html.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

glossary/nested-queries.html.title: Nested Queries
glossary/nested-queries.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
glossary/nested-queries.html.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
SQL is compositional i.e. you can use subqueries. Input and outputs are relations (multisets). Subqueries can be correlated.
Subqueries can be used in any of the following clauses: SELECT, FROM (called derived tables), WHERE (for instance, using IN, ANY, ALL) and HAVING
glossary/nested-queries.html.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

glossary/null.html.title: Null
glossary/null.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
glossary/null.html.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
NULL in SQL either implies that the value is missing i.e. exists but unknown or that it cannot be used yet
In SQL, there are 3 (not 2) boolean values: TRUE, FALSE and UNKNOWN. Furthermore, arithmetic operations produce NULL on NULL values whereas aggregate operations ignore NULL values

Apparently a lot of research on NULLs
glossary/null.html.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

?

glossary/semantics-of-a-sql-query.html.description:
?
Unit 1 - SQL
The nested loop way of executing a complex join query with select and project filters is a good conceptual way of looking at the semantics of the query though the optimizer will likely find an algebraically-equivalent more-efficient query execution strategy

How is Top-k evaluated?
?
Unit 1 - SQL
Top-k is evaluated inefficiently by modern databases
Top-k can be evaluated efficiently using dynamic programming and efficient factorization

literature-notes/danaparamita2011queryvi.title: QueryViz: Helping users understand SQL queries and their patterns
literature-notes/danaparamita2011queryvi.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
literature-notes/danaparamita2011queryvi.description:
#t #o #- #r #e #a #d #, # #J #o #n #a #t #h #a #n #- #D #a #n #a #p #a #r #a #m #i #t #a #, # #W #o #l #f #g #a #n #g #- #G #a #t #t #e #r #b #a #u #e #r
Jonathan Danaparamita, Wolfgang Gatterbauer (2011)
Tags: #to-read #Jonathan-Danaparamita #Wolfgang-Gatterbauer
Abstract We present QueryViz, a novel visualization tool for SQL queries that reduces the time needed to read and understand existing queries. It targets two principal audiences: (i) users who often issue the same or similar queries and who need to quickly browse through a repository of existing queries; and (ii) novices that try to familiarize themselves with the logic behind alternative patterns of SQL queries. QueryViz uses as input only two strings: the database schema and the SQL query. It can thus serve as light-weight add-on to existing database systems and is also available via an online interface at http://queryviz.com. In this demonstration, we explain our visual alphabet, walk through the visualization algorithm, and let users experience the difference in understanding SQL queries from text or our graphical representation while browsing through repositories of well-known textbook SQL queries.
Dataview: No results to show for list query.

literature-notes/gatterbauer2022principl.title: Principles of query visualization
literature-notes/gatterbauer2022principl.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
literature-notes/gatterbauer2022principl.description:
#t #o #- #r #e #a #d #, # #W #o #l #f #g #a #n #g #- #G #a #t #t #e #r #b #a #u #e #r #, # #C #o #d #y #- #D #u #n #n #e #, # #H #V #- #J #a #g #a #d #i #s #h #, # #M #i #r #e #k #- #R #i #e #d #e #w #a #l #d
Wolfgang Gatterbauer, Cody Dunne, HV Jagadish, Mirek Riedewald (2022)
Tags: #to-read #Wolfgang-Gatterbauer #Cody-Dunne #HV-Jagadish #Mirek-Riedewald
Abstract Query Visualization (QV) is the problem of transforming a given query into a graphical representation that helps humans understand its meaning. This task is notably different from designing a Visual Query Language (VQL) that helps a user compose a query. This article discusses the principles of relational query visualization and its potential for simplifying user interactions with relational data.
Dataview: No results to show for list query.
literature-notes/gatterbauer2022principl.author: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

literature-notes/gatterbauer2024reasonab.title: On the reasonable effectiveness of relational diagrams: Explaining relational query patterns and the pattern expressiveness of relational languages
literature-notes/gatterbauer2024reasonab.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
literature-notes/gatterbauer2024reasonab.description:
#t #o #- #r #e #a #d #, # #W #o #l #f #g #a #n #g #- #G #a #t #t #e #r #b #a #u #e #r #, # #C #o #d #y #- #D #u #n #n #e
Wolfgang Gatterbauer, Cody Dunne (2024)
Tags: #to-read #Wolfgang-Gatterbauer #Cody-Dunne
Abstract Comparing relational languages by their logical expressiveness is well understood. Less well understood is how to compare relational languages by their ability to represent relational query patterns. Indeed, what are query patterns other than "a certain way of writing a query"? And how can query patterns be defined across procedural and declarative languages, irrespective of their syntax? To the best of our knowledge, we provide the first semantic definition of relational query patterns by using a variant of structure-preserving mappings between the relational tables of queries. This formalism allows us to analyze the relative pattern expressiveness of relational language fragments and create a hierarchy of languages with equal logical expressiveness yet different pattern expressiveness. Notably, for the non-disjunctive language fragment, we show that relational calculus can express a larger class of patterns than the basic operators of relational algebra. Our language-independent definition of query patterns opens novel paths for assisting database users. For example, these patterns could be leveraged to create visual query representations that faithfully represent query patterns, speed up interpretation, and provide visual feedback during query editing. As a concrete example, we propose Relational Diagrams, a complete and sound diagrammatic representation of safe relational calculus that is provably (i) unambiguous, (ii) relationally complete, and (iii) able to represent all query patterns for unions of non-disjunctive queries. Among all diagrammatic representations for relational queries that we are aware of, ours is the only one with these three properties. Furthermore, our anonymously preregistered user study shows that Relational Diagrams allow users to recognize patterns meaningfully faster and more accurately than SQL.
Dataview: No results to show for list query.

literature-notes/van2019anytime.html.title: Anytime approximation in probabilistic databases via scaled dissociations
literature-notes/van2019anytime.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M14.5 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7.5L14.5 2z"></path><polyline points="14 2 14 8 20 8"></polyline></svg>
literature-notes/van2019anytime.html.description:
#P-hard #t #o #- #r #e #a #d #, # #M #a #a #r #t #e #n #- #V #a #n # #d #e #n # #H #e #u #v #e #l #, # #P #e #t #e #r #- #I #v #a #n #o #v #, # #W #o #l #f #g #a #n #g #- #G #a #t #t #e #r #b #a #u #e #r #, # #F #l #o #r #i #s #- #G #e #e #r #t #s #, # #M #a #r #t #i #n #- #T #h #e #o #b #a #l #d
Maarten Van den Heuvel, Peter Ivanov, Wolfgang Gatterbauer, Floris Geerts, Martin Theobald (2019)
Tags: #P-hard #to-read #Maarten-Van #den #Heuvel #Peter-Ivanov #Wolfgang-Gatterbauer #Floris-Geerts #Martin-Theobald
Abstract Speeding up probabilistic inference remains a key challenge in probabilistic databases (PDBs) and the related area of statistical relational learning (SRL). Since computing probabilities for query answers is #P-hard, even for fairly simple conjunctive queries, both the PDB and SRL communities have proposed a number of approximation techniques over the years. The two prevalent techniques are either (i) MCMC-style sampling or (ii) branch-and-bound (B&B) algorithms that iteratively improve model-based bounds using a combination of variable substitution and elimination. We propose a new anytime B&B approximation scheme that encompasses all prior model-based approximation schemes proposed in the PDB and SRL literature. Our approach relies on the novel idea of "scaled dissociation" which can improve both the upper and lower bounds of existing modelbased algorithms. We apply our approach to the well-studied problem of evaluating self-join-free conjunctive queries over tuple-independent PDBs, and show a consistent reduction in approximation error in our experiments on TPC-H, Yago3, and a synthetic benchmark setting.
Dataview: No results to show for list query.

streams/wolfgang-gatterbauer's-cs-7240-p.description:
Excel
PostgreSQL
Bag Semantics
Distinct
Semantics of a SQL Query
Nested Queries
Common Table Expressions
Correlated Nested Queries
Monotone Queries
SQL Patterns and Relational Diagrams
Union
Null
Join Types
Coalesce
Commutativity & Associativity
Matrix Chain Multiplication
Full Disjunction
Top-k Query

Are the following two queries the same
--- QUery 1 SELECT DISTINCT c.cname FROM company c WHERE c.cid NOT IN ( SELECT p.cid FROM product p WHERE p.price >= 25 ) -- Query 2 SELECT c.cname FROM company c, product p WHERE c.cid = p.pid GROUP BY c.cname HAVING MAX(p.price) < 25 Copy
?
No. The former would also return companies that produce no products whereas the latter will only return a company if a it produces at least one product
[Universal Quantifiers and Nested Queries]
While existential quantifier queries like "find all companies that make some products below 25" can be "unnested", universal quantifiers are like "find all companies that make all parts below 25" harder
--- Try 1 - NOT IN SELECT c.cname FROM company c WHERE c.cid NOT IN ( SELECT p.pid FROM product p WHERE p.price >= 25 ) --- NOT EXISTS SELECT c.cname FROM company c WHERE NOT EXISTS ( SELECT * FROM product p WHERE p.cid = c.cid AND p.price >= 25 ) --- ALL SELECT c.cname FROM company c WHERE 25 > ALL ( SELECT p.price FROM product p WHERE p.cid = c.cid ) -- GROUP BY SELECT DISTINCT c.cname FROM company c JOIN product p ON p.cid = c.cid GROUP BY c.cid HAVING MAX(p.price) < 25; Copy
Can you unnest the universal quantifier query without using group by?
?
No. Queries with universal quantifier are not monotonic.


PostgreSQL and pgAdmin set up
